ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Afghanistan); Police Forces of Afghanistan (2014-2021); Former Government of Afghanistan (2014-2021)
SOURCE: Afghanistan National Television; Noor TV; Digital Media Source; AP; RFE/RL; Negah TV; Afghan Islamic Press News Agency; Sedai Khelafat Radio (Afghanistan); Liveuamap; Xinhua; Ariana TV; Amaq; AFP; Sharq TV; TOLO News; Pajhwok Afghan News; Khaama Press
NOTES: 4 Islamic State suicide bombers stormed the national television station in Jalalabad city killing 4 state TV employees and 2 police officers. Islamic State claims to have brought about 30 fatalities in the attack. Total fatalities coded as 10 (including 4 suicide bombers).

On November 7th, 2-5 people, including 2 security guards, were killed and at least 20 civilians injured when 2 Islamic State suicide bombers attacked the Shamshad TV building in Kabul. Total fatalities coded as 4 (including 2 suicide bombers).

SOURCE: 1TV (Afghanistan); Pajhwok Afghan News; Amaq; AP; TOLO News; Khaama Press; AFP; Anadolu Agency
NOTES: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing on the pro-Iranian, Shiite Tabayan Cultural Center on the morning of December 28, 2017, in the Dasht-e Barchi area of Kabul City. Around 100 people had gathered for a seminar marking the 28th anniversary of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan; the center shares a building with the Afghan Voice Agency, an anti-IS radio station. Besides 1-3 suicide bombers, up to 3 other bombs were used in the attack. 50 people, including a journalist, were killed along with at least 1 bomber and 84-90 injured, including 9 journalists. The IS claimed killing 100, including officials and reporters, and wounding another 120; they criticized Tabayan for receiving support from Iran and promoting Shia Islam.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Afghanistan (2014-2021) National Directorate of Security; Civilians (Afghanistan); Journalists (Afghanistan)
NOTES: On April 30th, 29 people were killed and 49 injured, when 2 Islamic State suicide bombers detonated themselves near an NDS office in the Shashdarak area of Kabul. It is not clear whether the first attacked targeted the office itself, however the second attack occurred after police, NDS personnel, and journalists arrived at the scene. Of the 29 killed, 9 were journalists and 3 were police officers. Total fatalities coded as 31 (including 2 suicide bombers).

On 06-September-2018, 25 people were killed, including 2 Tolo News journalists, and 90 others wounded in a double suicide bombing conducted by Islamic State militants at a sports gym in the Dasht-i-Barchi area of Kabul city, Kabul district, Kabul province. Total fatalities coded as 27 (including 2 suicide bombers).
On 26-December-2018, unidentified armed militants fired a missile which hit the Neda-e Sobh-e Ghoryan Radio station in Ghoryan district, Herat province. No injuries or fatalities were reported.
On 12-March-2019, an Afghan journalist was wounded after a bomb exploded in his car in PD2 of Lashkargah city, Lashkargah district, Helmand. No group claimed responsibility.
On July 31 2019, 35 civilians including 2 journalists were killed and 27 were wounded when a Taliban-planted IED hit their bus in the Ab Khorma area of Bala Buluk district, Farah.
On 04 August 2019, a magnetic bomb planted by IS militants hit a bus carrying employees of the Khurshid TV station , killing 2 passersby and injuring 2-4 civilians, in Kabul city.

On September 24 2019, 4 civilians, including 2 children and a local journalist, were killed and at least 3 civilians were wounded by a bomb placed next to the gate of President Ashraf Ghani' campaign office in Kandahar city. It's unclear who planted the bomb.

On 30 November 2019, 1-3 policemen including a senior border commander were killed, 2 others and 1 journalist were wounded by a Taliban-planted bomb in the Jernamo area of Nawa-e Barakzayi district, Helmand. VOJ reported 3 policemen including a commander were killed. One source (AP) reported the event took place in Nad Ali district, while others reported it took place in Nawa-e Barakzayi.
On 30 November 2019, 1 border forces commander was killed and a local reporter was wounded by a roadside bomb in Nad Ali district, Helmand. It's unclear who planted the bomb.

SOURCE: Twitter; Taliban Twitter; AP; Pajhwok Afghan News; Liveuamap
NOTES: On 30 May 2020, 2 journalists were killed and 4 others were wounded when their bus was hit by a landmine in the Kolola Pushta area of Kabul city. IS claimed responsibility for the attack.

SOURCE: Pajhwok Afghan News; Afghan Islamic Press News Agency
NOTES: On 11 August 2020, a bomb damaged a radio station and a magazine's building in the Shah Koti area of Pul-e Khumri city, Baghlan. It's unclear who planted the bomb. No casualties occurred.
On 28 August 2020, 3 journalists were injured in a car bomb explosion planted by Taliban militants on Jawzjan-Mazar-e-Sharif highway in Charbolak district of Balkh province.

SOURCE: New York Times; AFP; Pajhwok Afghan News
NOTES: On 12 November 2020, 1 journalist was killed and 3 civilians including another journalist were wounded when a sticky bomb attached to his vehicle exploded in Lashkargah city, Helmand. It's unclear who planted the bomb. The journalist was threatened by the Taliban.

On 1 February 2021, a senior Afghan ministry of peace official and the founder of Khaama Press online press escaped unharmed after his car was hit by an unidentified militant'-planted IED blast in Shah Shaheed area of PD10, Kabul city.
Around 25 May 2021, the employee of a radio station was wounded after a mortar shelling of the city of Mehtar Lam, Laghman. Unclear who fired the mortar.

SOURCE: Pajhwok Afghan News; Afghan Islamic Press News Agency; Ariana TV; Undisclosed Source
NOTES: On 3 June 2021, 4 civilians including a journalist were killed and 4 were wounded when their vehicle hit a bomb in the Char Qala road in PD 6, Kabul city. The sister of a journalist was first wounded, but died on 6 June. It's unclear who planted the bomb.

SOURCE: Afghan Islamic Press News Agency; Reporterly (Afghanistan)
NOTES: On 14 July 2021, at least 21 civilians including a journalist were wounded when a bomb exploded near a police checkpoint in the Talashi Square, PD2, Jalalabad city, Nangarhar. It's unclear who planted it.
On 30 October 2020, a TNT device exploded outside the house of Albanian journalist Elidon Ndreka in Balldren (Lezhe), inflicting minor damage to the property. No fatalities reported.
Two Algerian people including a journalist were killed Friday in Algerias Khenchla province when a road side bomb planted by militants exploded in the province, about 450 km east of Algiers,

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Armenia); Journalists (Armenia); Civilians (France); Journalists (France); Civilians (Russia); Journalists (Russia)
SOURCE: Tert; Human Rights Ombudsman Of The Republic Of Artsakh
NOTES: On 1 October 2020, 3 civilians from Artsakh were killed and 6 others were wounded during the shelling of Khojavend (Martuni) city of Artsakh by the Azerbaijani army. Armenian, French and Russian journalists were wounded.
On 8 October 2020, 3 Russian journalists were wounded after the artillery and missile shelling of Shusha city by the Azerbaijani military forces.
On July 11, unidentified men threw bombs at the residence of the president of the Kalia press club, in Narail, injuring him and his wife.
On 18 May, an unidentified group hurled a hand bomb near the printing press of the daily Amar Desh at Tejgaon industrial area in Dhaka, Dhaka on Friday night.
On 6 Nov, a journalist was severely injured in an attack by unidentified persons who hurled three bombs at his house in the Badhghata area of Shyamnagar town (Satkhira, Khulna).

On 6 May 2019, in Vitoria, Espirito Santo, the car of a TV Reporting Station was blown up by three men who placed a bomb underneath in Bonfim neighbourhood to distract police. According to officials, the act was in response to police action in a drug trafficking event earlier in the day. No injuries were reported.
On 6 May 2019, in Vitoria, Espirito Santo, three supects blew up the car of a TV journalist.

On 10 March 2016, near Sittwe township (Sittwe District, Rakhine State), an explosion occured at a journalist's home. The journalist claimed he was targeted for his media outlet's coverage of controversial issues. He and his family were away from home at the time of the incident and no one was injured.

On 23 March 2021, in Lashio town (Lashio Township, Lashio District, Shan State), an unknown assailant attacked the house of Chief of Editor of Pyae Madaing News agency reportedly with a handmade bomb. Two of his children were injured.
Grenades thrown into journalist house.

A grenade was thrown into the house where a journalist and her mother were living. No fatalities. Prior to the event, journalist said having received several threats due to an investigation on suspected disappearances. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]
An explosive device attack takes place against Press Book Communications premises in Yaounde

The car of an investigative journalist from Radio France Internationale in Cameroon exploded outside his house, causing no injuries; it appears to be in connection with his coverage of the Cameroonian security forces

SOURCE: Journal du Cameroun; Cameroon Online; Camer.be; Xinhua; GardaWorld; AFP; RFI; Mimi Mefo
NOTES: On 6 January 2021, an IED planted by suspected Ambazonian separatists detonated on an official convoy around Njikwa (Momo, Nord-Ouest), killing 4 soldiers and the Momo divisional delegate of communication (total of 5 fatalities), and injuring 3 others. The delegation was travelling back after installing the Divisional Officers for Ngie and Njikwa.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Journalists (Central African Republic)
NOTES: 3 people were killed and several others injured after a photographer who was allegedly drunk dropped a grenade in the middle of a meeting of five evangelical churches after they took away his camera. He attempted to flee but was captured by a group of young people who beat him to death.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
NOTES: 2 journalists were seriously wounded by shrapnel from a grenade allegedly thrown by a police officer while they were covering a protest by residents of Kindu who were demanding to be allowed to stone two alleged thieves. The journalists were standing apart from the crowd and were reportedly directly targeted.

SOURCE: Anadolu Agency; Palestine News and Information Agency; AFP
NOTES: On May 4 2019, Israeli forces targeted the Anadolu News Agency office in Gaza city's Rimal neighbourhood in an airstrike with 5 missiles. The building was destroyed, but no injuries were reported.

SOURCE: Al Ghad (Jordan); PCHR: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights
NOTES: On 13 May 2021, the Israeli Air Force conducted a strike in the city Bayt Lahya (Gaza Strip, North Gaza). Israeli warplanes targeted with at least 20 missiles a residential neighborhood In Bayt Lahya near the Zaid intersection. Residential apartments [for rent], financial institutions, a law firm, companies and education centers were completely destroyed. 8 Palestinians were killed including 4 children, 7 are missing and 33 others including 10 children were wounded. The main road, electricity and communication networks as well as water pipers were also destroyed in the strikes, and 6 residential houses sustained severe damages. Israeli warplanes also targeted with one missile the Ministry of Transport and Communications' licensing headquarter in al Sheikh Zayid area in Bayt Lahya, partially destroying it. A vehicle belonging to the Careem Taxi Company was damaged in the airstrike and two journalists [Anadolu News Agency] travelling in the vehicle and the driver were wounded. Israeli warplanes targeted with 3 missiles a 4-storey house in the Bayt Lahya housing Project, killing 4 Palestinians including a pregnant woman and wounding 27 others including 10 children and 6 women. Nearby homes sheltering 91 Palestinians were destroyed.

SOURCE: PCHR: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights
NOTES: On 16 May 2021, at approximately 00:20, Israeli artillery forces opened fire and flare bombs on Rafah City. Some shells fell on 6 houses in the al-Shabourah refugee camp in the city, wounding 2, including a journalist. A number of houses were damaged.
On 19 May 2021, an Israeli aircraft struck a house in the Tel al Hawa neighbourhood of Gaza City. A reporter of the Turkish news agency Anadolu was injured from shrapnel as a result.

SOURCE: PCHR: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights
NOTES: On 19 May 2021, at approximately 04:30, Israeli warplanes targeted an apartment building with 2 missiles near the intersection in Gaza - Sheikh Radwan, killing a Radio announcer working for Al Aqsa and damaging the 4th and 5th floors of the building. Israeli warplanes also fired a missile at a car parked outside the home.

SOURCE: Arab News; PCHR: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights; Dunia Al Watan
NOTES: On 20 May 2021, Israeli aircraft struck a building in the city Gaza (Gaza Strip, Gaza), killing a local journalist who lived in the place. Israeli aircrafts also struck a vehicle in the city Gaza (Gaza Strip, Gaza), killing one person. At approximately 06:00, Israeli warplanes targeted the 5th floor of a residential building in Gaza City, wounding 5 children.

SOURCE: PCHR: Palestinian Centre for Human Rights
NOTES: On 20 May 2021, at approximately 14:00, Israeli warplanes targeted a 3-storey house in the Shaboura refugee camp of Rafah City, with 3 missiles. 4 Palestinians were wounded, including a journalist and a child and the house was destroyed. The house was targeted by a drone two days prior.

On 26 February 2018, early in the morning, unknown assailants planted a homemade explosive device comprising gas canisters at the entrance of a building housing a private television channel, which belonged to the leader of the far-right populist party LAOS, in Kallithea, Athens - South Athens. The device went off, causing minor damage. No injuries were reported.

On 17 December 2018, a bomb exploded at the headquarters of Skai tv station and Kathimerini newspaper in Neo Faliro. The blast caused a lot of damage but there were no injuries as the building had been evacuated after telephone warnings to other media. Popular Fighters Group (OLA) claimed responsibility for the attack on 10 January 2019 with a lengthy statement against mass media in general and SKAI tv in particular.

On 14 May, unknown arsonists targeted the car of a television crime reporter. The vehicle was parked outside her home in the northern suburb of Papagou in Athens and was blown up with a makeshift explosive device. Police believe this was a message sent by supporters of Dimitris Koufodinas demanding a seventh furlough for the jailed hitman of the now defunct group November 17, who is on hunger strike. On 21 May the group Incendiary Anti-police Reporters claimed responsibility. [size=no report]

On 10 February 2021, a homemade incendiary device made of gas canisters was left at the entrance of a building that was housing the offices of 3 newspapers in Pangrati, Athens - Central Athens. The blast damaged the exterior of the building. No injuries were reported.

On 5 October, suspected militants threw a grenade at a security patrol (assumed police) outside the Deputy Commissioner's office in Anantnag town (J&K). 14 people including a policeman and a journalist were injured when the grenade exploded on the roadside nearby.
On June 17, while covering the battle in Falluja, an Iraqi journalist was wounded by a mortar shell presumably launched by Islamic State militants, without excluding friendly fire.

On July 1, an Iraqi journalist covering the battlefront was severely wounded by the explosion of a landmine in the area of Qayyara, the explosive device was most likely planted by Islamic State militants.
On July 1, an Iraqi photojournalist was wounded by the explosion of an IED while covering the battle in Mosul, the IED was presumably planted by Islamic State militants.

On Oct 21, 3 IS militants stormed a power plant in a town north of Kirkuk, killing at least 13 workers, including four Iranians, before blowing themselves up as police arrived, also a local TV reporter covering the clashes was also killed.
On November 18th, 2016, an Iraqi journalist was injured when a rocket fell next to him in Al-Hurriya neighbourhood in Mosul city, Ninewa. No fatalities were reported.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Iraq (2014-2018) Popular Mobilization Forces
NOTES: On Nov 25, IS militants targeted PMF fighters in Telafar Airport by mortar shelling, injuring one PMF fighter and a cameraman was injured.
On Jan 16th, a reporter and his accompanying cameraman were injured as the result of an IS militant drone which dropped explosives in the area they were covering military advances in eastern Mosul.
On Feb 14, a powerful blast wave from ISIS SVBIED injures Algerian journalist embedded with PMF near Tel Afar.
A female reporter working for an Iraqi Kurdish channel has been killed in Mosul on 25 Feb 2017 in a suspected IS roadside bomb attack while covering clashes between Iraqi government forces.

On March 14, 2017, a mortar believed to be fired by militants landed near a Rudaw team embedded with Iraqi forces near Ashur hotel (Old City district) in the centre of Mosul, causing severe respiratory problems among the advancing Iraqi soldiers and media.

SOURCE: Asharq AlAwsat; Anadolu Agency; Liveuamap; Peninsula (Qatar); Press TV; Emirates News Agency; Xinhua; AP; Iraq News Gazette; Al Jazeera
NOTES: Iraqi Kurdish journalist Bakhtiyar Addad and French Journalist Stephan Villeneuve were killed in a landmine explosion while covering clashes in Mosul's Old City district.

SOURCE: AP; Press TV; Iraq News Gazette; Xinhua
NOTES: Swiss journalist Veronique Robert was hit by a mine blast in Mosul and died from injuries suffered from the blast.

SOURCE: Ayn Al Iraq News; Press TV; All Iraq News Agency; Baghdad Post
NOTES: A Kerbala satellite channel photographer accompanying Iraqi Forces was killed by an IED explosion in Tal Afar
Iraqi war photographer Hamza Al-Aboudi was killed by a mortar shell near Hawija while covering the battle.
An Iraqi war photographer was killed by the explosion of a presumed Islamic State car bomb in the area of Mutaibija.

On Oct 06, a drone or missile strike was reported to have hit the headquarters of Al-Forat TV station in Baghdad. Al-Forat is a TV station affiliated with the National Wisdom (Hikmah) Movement. No reported injuries or fatalities.

On Nov 17, an unidentified rocket reportedly hit a media firm in al-Karrada district in Baghdad which houses studios for several local and foreign TV channels, killing 1 person. The missile was reportedly fired from the Camp Sara area.
On Mar 9, an unidentified armed group targeted a building using RBGs housing al-Wafaa TV station which is affiliated to an MP in Najaf city causing only material damages.
On 3 September 2020, a Kurdish photojournalist was killed when an unidentified roadside bomb detonated on a unit of the Iraqi Military in northern Iraq. An exact location was not reported.
On 6 March 2021, an unidentified armed group targeted a journalist's vehicle using an IED in Abu Rummaneh area of Amara City (Missan) causing material damages.

On 18 June 2021, an unidentified explosive device detonated in the home of an Arab Israeli reporter who works for Ynet in the Arab affairs section, in Baqa al Gharbiyyeh (Hadera, Haifa). The building was empty when the device exploded. This is the second attempt on the reporter's life who was targeted by a shooting two weeks ago.

Property destruction: On Feb 2 2019, an unidentified group targeted the 'Al Jadid' newspaper headquarters in Beirut by throwing a grenade from a moving car. The damage cause by the grenade was limited to material damage.

ACTOR1: Operation Unified Protector: NATO Mission in Libya (2011-2011)
NOTES: Three killed and fifteen injured during a NATO airstrike on state television headquarters. Three targeted satellites were destroyed, but the station remained on the air.

In the eastern city of Benghazi, an independent TV station reported an unknown attacker hurled a hand grenade at its building. An employee at Libya Al-Hurra, Tareq el-Issawi, said a colleague was injured in the minor explosion.

The Tripoli headquarters of Libyas Alassema privately owned television channel were attacked when three rocket-propelled grenades were fired at the building, and that a guard was lightly wounded. The assailants ransacked offices and abducted several employees for a few hours.
The Al-Assima satellite TV station owners home in the Tripoli suburb of Gurji was bombed at around 5 a.m. on 20 February, causing major damage, injuring a journalist and even shaking nearby homes.
The Al-Jazeera TV offices in Tripoli were hit by a reported grenade attack.
In Leithi district of Benghazi, a friend of a Libya Herald reporter was killed and two others seriously injured when a missile hit their car. It is not known who fired it.
A rocket attack (RPG) on Benghazi Radio's broadcasting studios slightly injured a number of people, including the poet Khadija Bsikri.
On January 19, a journalist was killed by shrapnel from a shell while he accompanied a militia patrolling the area of Qasr Bin Ghasir.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
NOTES: On September 8, a Hungarian journalist was wounded by an LNA airstrike in Salah Aldeen.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
ACTOR2: Military Forces of Libya (2016-2021) Government of National Accord
NOTES: On 13 September 2019, an LNA airstrike targeted a convoy belonging to the GNA in Sirte (Sirt, West), injuring a photojournalist that was accompanying the convoy.
On April 2, 2018 in Bijelo Polje, Montenegro, a bomb was thrown at a house of a journalist Sead Sadikovic. Police stated that Sadikovic was attacked because of his journalist work.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On 20 February 2018, cadres of Netra Bikram Chand-led Communist Party of Nepal exploded an IED near Bijayapur river in Pokhara city (Kaski district). A policeman and a journalist sustained injuries in the blast.
Unknown individuals have destroyed a radio station run by the Broadcasting Corporation of Abia (BCA) with explosives.

ACTOR1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
NOTES: Suicide bombers in the Nigerian capital Abuja detonated their ordinance in a newspaper office. 37 killed, 100 injured. Conflicting reports on the number of deaths, many have the number as low a 10. Boko Haram later claimed responsibility, threatening further attacks on media offices around the country.

ACTOR1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
NOTES: A suicide bomber hits a second newspaper officer in Kaduna, three killed. The two blasts came minutes apart. A third blast came two hours later and killed four more civilians.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Pakistan); ANP: Awami National Party; Journalists (Pakistan)
NOTES: At least 43 people were killed and 100 others injured in a suicide bomb blast at a rally organized by the ANP to celebrate the renaming of the NWFP in Timergara. Journalists and policemen were among those injured. 10 others later died from their injuries. The Swat chapter of the TTP claimed responsibility for the attack, calling the ANP their major enemy.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan); Government of Pakistan (2008-2013); Shiite Muslim Group (Pakistan); Labour Group (Pakistan)
NOTES: 11 people were killed, including a TV journalist and 2 senior policemen, and at least 35 others injured, including 5 journalists and an MNA, in a suicide blast outside the Civil Hospital, claimed by the LeJ. An attack had occurred earlier against a Shiite Muslim bank manager which killed him, and injured 2 others, and which had allegedly brought the police and journalists to the hospital. Following the bombings, unidentified gunmen engaged in aerial firing causing panic.

On April 17, at least 34 IDPs were killed when 2 burqa-clad suicide bombers attacks against a crowd which were collecting aid handouts. More than 60 were also injured, while LeJ took responsibility for the attack. At least 1 journalist was among the dead.
Seven persons were injured when suspected. TTP men hurled hand-grenades at the houses of two local journalists in Bhai Cheena near Khar, the headquarters of Bajaur Agency, on 7 July 2010.
Six people were hurt when UAM hurled hand grenades on the house of a local journalist in Khar on 26 July 2010.
A remote bomb planted in the car of a senior tribal journalist was detonated in Peshawar. The journalist was killed in the blast.
Unidentified culprits hurled a hand grenade at Right Vision News reporter Saeedullah Marwat's house, which failed to explode.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Pakistan (2008-2013) Pakistan Rangers; Journalists (Pakistan); Civilians (Pakistan)
NOTES: Two bomb blasts by TTP militants in Karachi took place killing three people and injuring 11 others, including a journalist besides police and Rangers personnel.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan); Aid Workers (Pakistan); UN: United Nations
SOURCE: Aid Worker Security Database; Daily Times (Pakistan); Right Vision News; BBC News
NOTES: At least 92 people were killed and more than 120 injured in twin blasts in Quetta city. The first was a suicide bombing at a snooker club on the basement of a building followed by the explosion of a remote controlled IED bomb attached on a car (coded separately PAK15603) outside the building as police, media persons and rescuers were rushing to the site. In the two incident 9 policemen, 25 rescue workers and 3 journalists were killed. One UN employee was killed in the suicide attack. LeJ is suspected of having carried out the attacks in retaliation for the recent killing of a Sunni cleric. (Fatality count divided into two events.)

SOURCE: Aid Worker Security Database; Right Vision News; BBC News; Daily Times (Pakistan)
NOTES: At least 92 people were killed and more than 120 injured in twin blasts in Quetta city. The first was a suicide bombing at a snooker club (coded separately PAK15602) on the basement of a building followed by a remote controlled IED bomb attached on a car outside the building as police, media persons and rescuers were rushing to the site. In the two incident 9 policemen, 25 rescue workers, 3 journalists were killed. LeJ is suspected of having carried out the attacks in retaliation for the recent killing of a Sunni cleric. (Fatality count divided into two events.)
An unidentified armed group fired rockets into Quetta causing damage to property and an explosion at a private TV channel office resulting in casualties.

At least 22 people, including a journalist, were injured in a bomb blast in Sibi. An explosive device was planted in a motorcycle parked outside a restaurant and it was detonated by remote control. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
On October 29, four hand grenade attacks created panic and fear in Dadu (Sindh). Unidentified motorcyclists threw a hand grenade at the local press club. No group claimed responsibility.

At least 15 people, including children, journalists and security officials, were injured in three separate bomb attacks targeting Shi'i Muslims in different areas of Karachi. No group has claimed responsibility.

An explosion occurred close to Imambargah Abul Fazal in North Nazim Abad injuring 8 persons including 2 police men, 2 reporters of a private TV channel and a camera man. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Two powerful and simultaneous explosions in the Ancholi area of Karachi, killed at least five persons, including an associate producer of Geo News and a child, and injuring at least 20. The bombs were fixed to motorbikes and detonated by remote control device. Four shops, four motorbikes and four vehicles were destroyed in the blasts. No group has claimed responsibility for the blasts.

Militants hurled hand grenade and then opened fire at the office of a private media group, hurting two security guards. According to police the security guard had sustained bullet injuries in the firing at Qayyumabad area of the city. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

On April 6, unknown men hurled a hand grenade at the house of a journalist in Jhang city (Punjab). However, the journalist, Jamshid Baghwan, remained unhurt. The blast also damaged nearby houses in the area.
On May 26, unidentified persons lobbed a hand-grenade into the house of a local journalist but it caused no casualty in Jamrud Tehsil of Khyber Agency (FATA).
Two employees of a private TV channel Dunya News were wounded when two unidentified men on a motorcycle hurled a cracker at their office located in Karachi.
2 employees of Dunya News were injured when unidentified motorcycle riders threw a hand grenade into their office in Faisalabad.

Three people were injured after an explosion occurred outside the office of Din News in Lahore. Initial investigations suggest that a cracker caused the powerful blast, no group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Unidentified attackers hurled a grenade at the Sargodha Bureau of Express News TV channel Monday evening, the channel's website reported. No loss of life was reported, however, the channel claimed that a security guard was injured and the building's exterior was damaged in the cracker attack.

Two persons riding a motorcycle hurled hand-grenade at the office of ARY News in Sector F-7/4, causing serious injuries to the driver of DSNG van. The perpetrators left a pamphlet at the scene claiming the government must stop operation Zarb-e-Azb. Rumors were quick to circulate that the attack was carried out by ISIS however, with no official claim, and with the attack being so different from the group's usual tactics the claim is not substantiated.

Twelve persons, including a journalist, were killed while 39 others sustained injuries when a suicide bomber targeted the tribal Khassadar force in the Karkhano Market close to the Peshawar boundary with Khyber Agency, Tehreek-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack.

On 8 August, at least 93 people were killed and 117 others injured when bomb exploded at Civil Hospital Quetta city. The explosion occurred when lawyers and some journalists gathered at the hospital after the death of Balochistan Bar Association's president Bilal Anwar Kasi in an armed attack earlier the same morning. Jamat-ul-Ahrar claimed responsibility for both attacks.

On September 5, two coordinated IEDs exploded at Khezai Chowk locality of Quetta city (Quetta, Balochistan) killing a rescue worker and injuring 10 others including six policemen and, a TV reporter and cameraman. The first IED exploded at the office of a transport company at Khezai Chowk. As the police, rescue workers and media gathered at the explosion site, the second IED went off.

SOURCE: Asian News International; South Asia Terrorism Portal; Dawn (Pakistan)
NOTES: On 10 October 2021, a journalist was killed and two others injured in a grenade attack on the RCD Highway in Hub town (Las Bela, Balochistan). BLA claimed responsibility for the attack.

On 18 March 2018, a radio broadcaster was left unscathed in a grenade attack by unidentified assailants in Barangay Bitano, Legazpi (Albay, Bicol Region). Police said the motive for the attack was likely related to the broadcaster's work as a journalist.

On 5th January, several unidentified individuals put a home-made explosive device into a mailbox of Andrei Timesko, a journalist based in St. Petersburg The device exploded prematurely, so no one was injured. Two days later the same individuals returned, did the same and in addition poured a liquid in front of the house. According to him, these people were probably hooilgans, taking revenge after the journalist published several reports about them.
radio station targeted in IED attack. unnamed
one journalist killed, two others, in IED attack, perp unnamed
one reporter wounded in mortar attack. unnamed
two healthcare workers, one journalist, one driver killed in IED attack. unnamed
Two unknown men attacked with two grenades, HornAfrik private TV and radio headquarters in Mogadishu, but no one was wounded in the attack
Another journalist was killed in a bomb attack in Mogadishu.
An independent radio station was targeted with mortars in the capital Mogadishu. One reporter was wounded when a mortar shell hit part of the building.
A suicide bomb attack outside the Ethiopian consulate in Hargeisa, Somaliland, injured three journalists.

On 3 December 2009, Al Shabaab suicide bomber detonated himself at a Banadir University graduation event at the Shamo hotel in Mogadishu-Wadajir district (Wadajir, Banadir). Thirty people were killed including four ministers, two Journalists and several others were injured.

Unidentified men threw hand grenades to the offices of Voice of Mudug, Radio Hobyo and Radio Galkacyo in Galkacyo, injuring 4 people, among them 3 journalists. A bomb went off at a press conference given by the spokesman for the Islamist al-Shahaab militia at a police college in a northern district of the capital, that left around a dozen people injured including about eight journalists who were seriously hurt.
AOGs attacked Shabelle Media Network offices with bombs and hand grenades. habelle Media Network offices relocated from Bakara Market to a TFG controlled area near the airport in May 2010.

A pair of assailants lobbed a grenade Monday evening at Horseed FM, a private radio station broadcasting from the port city of Bossasso. After the grenade exploded, one of the attackers began shooting at an adjacent cafe. No deaths reported.
Witnesses said two suicide bomb attacks at a restaurant killed on Thursday afternoon at least 10 people, among 3 Somali journalists and wounded twenty people.

Unknown attacker(s) hurled a hand grenade into the compound of Radio Baydhabo in the night of 02-03/03. The exact motive is still unclear but local sources indicate that the owner of the radio had received death threats from al Shabaab because of a anti-al Shabaab broadcast. No casualties were reported. Three suspects were arrested over the next few days.

A vehicle laden with explosives detonates near a bus outside the National Theatre building, causing the death of ten, including a journalist, and injuring fifteen others. Al Shabaab claimed responsibly for the attack, claiming their target was a government official of Banaadir Region, Ahmed Khalif 'Ereg', in an effort of revenge for the death of al Shabaab fighters in recent days. Other reports have the causality count numbering 35.

Unidentified attackers hurled a hand grenade at the front gate of Risala Radio Station in Suuq Yaraha area (Hamar Jab Jab District) in the evening of 16/04. The motive of the attack is unknown. No casualties were reported.
An explosion at KPP junction targeting a journalist, Abdi Liman Sharmake, detonates causing injuries.
Unidentified assailants threw two grenades at the Galkayo offices of Radio Daljir, causing property damage but no injury.

Unidentified attackers hurled a hand grenade at the privately-owned Radio Daljir in Israac neighbourhood (Galkacyo North) in the evening of 15/10. The motive is unknown. The stations security guards opened fire after the blast. No casualties were reported.
Unidentified attackers threw a hand grenade against the Radio Daljir compound; causalities not known. Radio Daljir is anti-al Shabaab.

Unidentified attackers threw a hand grenade at Radio Daljir compound in Israac neighbourhood in Galkacyo (North) in the evening of 07/03.The motive of the attack is unclear. No casualties were reported. The perpetrators escaped from the scene. Radio Daljir had already been targeted by hand-grenade attacks in the past and several of its journalists were assassinated. Radio Daljir is owned by a Somali American citizen and runs several programs against al Shabaab and Somali pirates.
21 June. A civilian journalist was killed by a bomb planted by an unidentified armed group in the Banadir region.

A magnetic IED explosion targeted a local journalist at Km-4 Junction of Hodan District in the night of 09/11. The journalist was reportedly injured and lost one leg in the explosion. The reason behind the attack remains unknown. No other casualties were reported.

A suicide bomber detonated his vest in Barwaqo teashop next to Dahabshiil office in Horseed neighbourhood in Baidoa in the afternoon of 05/12. Four minutes later, a VBIED (Toyota double-cabin), parked in front of an adjacent hotel was detonated. Police fired gunshots thinking the suspected al Shabaab operative conducting the explosions is among the people fleeing. The two teashops were popular among the residents of Baidoa who used to spend their evenings there. Bay regional police commander confirmed the death of 20 people (50+ injured), including the two suicide bombers, killed in the twin explosions and more than 30 others injured. The people killed in the attack include a security guard working for local security, journalists a man recently nominated as the deputy speaker of SW6 state. A man from Harin clan was reportedly arrested in the following security operation conducted by AMISOM/SNG for bailing out the suicide bomber and his vehicle after it was detained by police station few days ago.
Unidentified persons attacked the Radio Galkayo building with a pair of hand grenades. Two journalists reported injuries.

Unidentified attackers hurled two hand grenades at Radio Galkacyo Station in Israac neighbourhood (Galkacyo North) in the evening of 16/01. No casualties were reported. The perpetrators escaped. This is the second attack targeted at the radio station within two weeks. On the eve of the New Year, two hand grenades were hurled at the same station.

An IED attached to a vehicle belonging to a journalist exploded in the vicinity of KM4 (Hodan District) in the afternoon of 03/12. The victim was seriously injured and she was apparently working for a government run media under the Ministry of Information. It was later reported the victim had succumb to her injuries.

A suicide bomber, driving a vehicle rigged with explosives attempted to evade a security patrol in Bondhere, crashing the car into the building wall of a radio station, causing the explosives to detonate. Apart from the death of the driver, four others were injured. Shabelle Media Network reports three dead. Target and perpetrator identity not known.

IED placed under a vehicle belonging to a Universal TV journalist exploded in front of Cinema Supper in Hamarweyne district. The journalist was severely injured in the blast and admitted to hospital for treatment while two bystanders were also wounded. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. The attack may have occurred the previous day.
22 April, 23:00EAT, Banadir Junction, Mogadishu: a Somali journalist survived the detonation of an under-vehicle improvised explosive device (UVIED). No other injury reported.
An under vehicle IED targets a journalist. Perpetrators not reported by source.
11th December, 1800, Wadajir, Mogadishu: A UVIED exploded killing the occupant, a TV journalist. Perpetrators not named by the source.
04 December. Journalist and chairman of Human Rights Journalist (HRJ) organization Ismail Sheikh Khalifa critically injured in a car bomb attack in Mogadishu's Waberi district.
22 December. Mogadishu twin blasts claimed by AS killed at least 20 people and wounded another 40. Four journalists were among the dead.
15 August. A cameraman working for the Somali military was killed in an explosive attack by Al Shabaab militants in Awdheegle.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
NOTES: On 1 January 2021, US forces in coordination with government security forces (SNA) conducted two airstrikes targeting an Al Shabaab militant compound in the vicinity of Qunyo Barrow village (Jilib, Middle Juba). The strike destroyed (AS-affiliated) Al Furqaan radio station and killed three journalists and one other militant

On 20 November 2021, an Al Shabaab suicide bomber detonated, targeting journalists at the Taalada Daljirka Dahson (unknown soldier monument) neighborhood, near the ministry of sports in Mogadishu - Shangaani (Banadir). The directors of Radio Mogadishu and National TV were coming out from a restaurant and moving toward a fuel station. The Director of Radio Mogadishu was killed, while the Director of National TV and three others, including the driver, were rushed to hospital for emergency treatment.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: Daily News offices bombed
Daily News headquarters bombed by suspected ZANU-PF affiliates
Voice of the People radio station bombed. No injuries
A media activist was injured as a result of shrapnel from a mortar shell fired by Islamic State fighters in Al Bab city in the suburbs of Aleppo governorate.
A media activist died of injuries he sustained by the firing of a shell by Islamic State fighters in Yarmouk Basin in Dar'a governorate.
A media activist was injured as a result of a mortar shell that fell near him and that was fired by Islamic State fighters into Kahil town in Dar'a governorate.
An explosive charge planted by unidentified armed forces exploded targeting a car in Bait Jan town in Rural Damascus, which killed one man who works as a media activist.
An IED from an unidentified group exploded in a car in Beit Jenn, killing a media activist.
Warplanes, believed to be Syrian or Russian, bombarded Dar'a city. Al Jazeera journalist 'Mohamed Nour' was severely injured in the airstrike. 5 civilians were also reported dead.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: On 22 February 2017, regime warplanes conducted airstrikes targeting Sheikh Mustafa and Maaret Harma villages in Idleb governorate. As a result, 1 civilian was injured, and the office of Syrian Press Center in Ma'aret Harma village and its equipment were partially damaged. There were no fatalities.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Regime and/or Russian warplanes and regime helicopters targeted with rockets and barrel bombs Al-Latamna, Tiba Elemama and Kafr Zeita in Hama. The airstrikes killed Mohammad Abu Al-Yazid Taftanaz the reporter of Jisr Satellite Channel, and injured a number of media activists such as Saif Al-Abdullah, Mohammad Hweish, Taim Al-Yousif, and Iyad Abu Al-Joud. One fatality coded for Kafr Zeita.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Material damages reported after regime warplanes carried out raids targeted places in Kafr Zita area and Tal Hawash village in the northern countryside of Hama. The airstrikes killed the reporter of Jisr Satellite Channel, and injured a number of media activists . One fatality coded toKafr Zeita.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: 16 people, including 11 fighters of Islamic factions, a media activist for an Islamic movement, and 4 paramedics, were killed in tens of raids by regime warplanes on places in al-Janabrah and Tal Hawash in the northwestern countryside of Hama. 16 fatalities split evenly between the 2 locations.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Warplanes, likely regime and/or Russian, and regime helicopters targeted with rockets and barrel bombs Al-Latamna city in Hama. The airstrikes in Latamana and Kafr Zeita killed Mohammad Abu Al-Yazid Taftanaz the reporter of Jisr Satellite Channel, and injured a number of media activists such as Saif Al-Abdullah, Mohammad Hweish, Taim Al-Yousif, and Iyad Abu Al-Joud. One fatality coded toKafr Zeita.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Regime forces carried out 4 missile attacks on civilian areas in Tal Hawash. 16 people, including 11 fighters of Islamic factions, a media activist for an Islamic movement, and 4 paramedics, were also killed in tens of raids by regime warplanes on places in al-Janabrah and Tal Hawash in the northwestern countryside of Hama. 16 fatalities split evenly between the 2 locations.
A landmine planted by IS exploded in Babiri village front in Aleppo, which killed the media activist while he was in the area covering the battles between Syrian regime forces and IS.
The Islamic State bombarded the eastern countryside of Aleppo with shells. One photographer died as a result.
Two Russian journalists were injured in an IS drone (Quadcopter) strike in Deir ez-Zor city.
A suspected Russian warplane's missile struck near Al-Janoudiya town in Idleb, killing a media activist .

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Regime and Russian warplanes bombed Jisr-Ash-Sugur in Idleb province, killing a media activist and injuring one civilian.
Four local journalists were wounded when an IS mortar shell fell near them on their way to Maamoun neighbourhood in Ar-Raqqa city.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
SOURCE: Liveuamap; SOHR; White Helmets; SNHR; SHAM
NOTES: Two raids were carried out by regime warplanes that targeted areas in Hazza town in Eastern Ghouta which killed 5 people, including children and journalist, and the wounding of 2 women and 2 men. Suspected regime ground forces also fired an artillery shell on Hezzeh.

Five civilians, including two children, two female citizens and a media activist, died in an airstrike carried out by warplanes on areas in Hazzeh (Corrected from: Hazet Al-Wake'ah) town in Eastern Ghouta.
An explosion of an explosive device heard in a market area in Idlib city injured a media activist and a child.
Journalist for Syrian Media Organization killed in roadside bombing in Daraa.
A shell landed on an area in the Al-Sad neighborhood of Dar'a city, killing a media activist for a rebel faction.
A landmine previously planted by IS detonated in al-Barghuthiya in southern Hama countryside, killing a QDW news reporter.
Three journalists from Hawar news were killed in explosion on the road between Shaddadah-Deir-ez-Zor. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

An IS Suicide VBIED detonated near a QSD checkpoint in Abu Fas in southern al-Hasakeh countryside, killing between 24-50 civilians including 2 media activists as well as the IS perpetrator. Total fatalities coded to 25 to account for SVBIED driver.

36 persons including 12 children, four women, a media activist, were killed as a result of the rocket shelling on areas on Douma, Ein Tarma, Jesrin, Misraba and Saqba in Eastern Ghota. 18 fatalities were coded before on events in Ein Tarma, Jisrin and Misraba. The remaining 18 fatalities were distributed over Douma, Saqba and Hamouriyah.

36 persons including 12 children, four women, a media activist, were killed as a result of the rocket shelling on areas on Douma, Ein Tarma, Jesrin, Misraba and Saqba in Eastern Ghota. 18 fatalities were coded before on events in Ein Tarma, Jisrin and Misraba. The remaining 18 fatalities were distributed over Douma, Saqba and Hamouriyah.

36 persons including 12 children, four women, a media activist, were killed as a result of the rocket shelling on areas on Douma, Ein Tarma, Jesrin, Misraba and Saqba in Eastern Ghota. 18 fatalities were coded before on events in Ein Tarma, Jisrin and Misraba. The remaining 18 fatalities were distributed over Douma, Saqba and Hamouriyah.

SOURCE: White Helmets; SHAM; Liveuamap; SNHR; SOHR
NOTES: The Syrian army shelled Hamouriya city in Rural Damascus province, which killed 8 civilians, including 2 women and a media activist, and injured several others. Another civilian later died from wounds sustained.
A mine blast in Deir-ez-Zor governorate injured five Russian soldiers and four Russian reporters. No fatalities were reported.
The Russian warplanes conducted several airstrikes on Iba'a news agency in the northern countryside of Hama which led to killing 1 journalist and injuring another one.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: Regime helicopters and Russian warplanes targeted Abu Dali town in southern Idleb, injuring Taher Alomar, a reporter who works for an FSA channel as well as his cameraman and destroying their vehicle. No fatalities reported.

Turkish forces shelled areas in the Raju sub-district of Aleppo, including Kraj Raju village which was hit with missiles. Four members of a media crew were injured by Turkish operations in the area, in addition to 7 more civilians. No fatalities reported.
On March 4th, a civilian journalist succumbed to the injuries he sustained a few days prior when Syrian and/or Russian warplanes carried out airstrikes on Kafr Batna.
A regime military photographer was killed by a landmine explosion on the road near the village of Azizyeh.
An explosion of landmine previously planted by the YPG occurred in Afrin city which killed between 1 to 7 civilians, 1 journalist and 3 Operation Olive Branch soldiers. Total fatalities coded as 5.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force; Military Forces of Russia (2000-)
SOURCE: SNHR; Undisclosed Source; Airwars; SOHR; SHAM
NOTES: The Syrian army shelled Ein Terma town in Rural Damascus in conjunction with Russian and regime airstrikes on the town which led to the killing of 8 civilians including 1 journalist and the injury of several other civilians.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force; Military Forces of Russia (2000-)
SOURCE: Liveuamap; Undisclosed Source; SHAM; SNHR; SOHR
NOTES: The Syrian regime fired rockets and artillery on Duma city in the Eastern Ghouta in conjunction with dozens Russian and regime airstrikes on the town which led to the killing of 2 civilians including 1 journalist and the injury of several 8 other civilians. Russian warplanes reportedly used incendiary munitions.

The Syrian army targeted a car belong to a local organization on the road between Al-Qahera and Ankawi in Hama countryside with guided missile, which led to the killing of 1 media activist and the injury of 2 other civilians.
An IED planted by an unidentified armed group detonated targeting the vehicle of a female media activist in Salqin in western Idleb countryside and wounding her. No fatalities were reported.
Military Forces of Turkey shelled areas in Tell Abiad including Munbatih area in northern Ar-Raqqa countryside, wounding 2 members of a media team present in the area. No fatalities were reported.
On 9 March 2019, regime and loyalist militia forces shelled the town of Tall al-Sakhr, wounding a media activist. No fatalities were reported.

SOURCE: White Helmets; Aid Worker Security Database; Liveuamap; SNHR
NOTES: On 9 March 2019, Russian warplanes carried out air raids on the village of Mintar in Idleb countryside, impacting service and rescue cars of Civil Defense, partially damaging them, and killing 5 civilians including a Syrian Civil Defence volunteer, and a media activist, as well as 2 women and 1 child, while wounding 6 others, including 2 children and 2 SCD. 5 fatalities

On 10 March 2019, regime forces fired artillery and missiles at the town of Khan Shaykun which killed 4 civilians including 1 child, 1 woman and 1 media activist, and wounded 4 children, and 1 woman. Total fatalities coded to 4.
On 19 March 2019, regime forces shelled the village of Al-Haweeja which injured a woman and two media activists. No fatalities were reported.

On March 23, 2019 an IED, planted by unidentified armed group, hit the vehicle carrying the NBC News team near Baghouz. It was reported that the explosion killed the driver and injured the other passengers.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force; Military Forces of Russia (2000-)
NOTES: On 24 May 2019, Russian warplanes conducted multiple airstrikes in conjunction with regime helicopters deploying barrel bombs and regime ground forces firing artillery shells targeting Al-Hibet town in Idleb governorate. As a result, 2 civilian journalists were wounded and no fatalities were reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Aid Workers (Syria); Journalists (Syria); Aid Workers (Syria); Journalists (Syria)
NOTES: On 17 June 2019, an IED planted by an unidentified armed group in Sarmada in northern Idleb countryside detonated targeting the vehicle of an aid organization, wounding 2 individuals as a result. A media activist, died in a Turkish hospital on 23/06 from injuries sustained during the explosion.

On 27 June, 2019, an IED planted by an unidentified armed group on Mazzeh highway in Kafr Sousah neighborhood of Damascus city detonated targeting the vehicle of a prominent pro-regime news reporter. While the reporter survived the attack, his wife and son were wounded. No fatalities were reported.

On 13 October 2019, Turkish warplanes hit a convoy of civilians traveling through the Ras Al Ain area, killing between 4 and 15 civilians, including 2 journalists and a documentary videographer, and 4 QSD fighters and wounding at least 74. Total fatalities coded to 8.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Russia (2000-) Military Police
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Syria); Journalists (Syria); Health Workers (Syria); HS: Kurdish Red Crescent
NOTES: On 29 October 2019, Turkish forces fired artillery shells that hit a Russian military police convoy that was accompanied by a media delegation visiting the Darbasiyah border crossing. As a result, 5 individuals from the media delegation, 2 Kurdish Red Crescent workers and at least 2 Russian soldiers were wounded. No fatalities were reported.

On 9 November 2019, Turkish forces fired artillery shells targeting Um Shu'ayfah village in Al-Hasakeh governorate. As a result, 3 journalists and 4 Syrian regime forces members were wounded and no fatalities were reported.
On 11 November 2019, regime ground forces shelled the town of Kafruma which killed a woman and a male media activists and set fire to a mosque. Total fatalities coded to 2.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Syrian Arab Air Force
NOTES: On 04 February, 2020, regime and Russian warplanes carried out airstrikes on Ariha in Idleb countryside, killing 2 civilians, one of them is a media activist.
On 20 February, 2020, Russian warplanes carried out airstrikes on the outskirts of Maaret Al Naasan in Idleb countryside, killing 1 journalist.
On 2 May 2020, a landmine planted by an unknown armed group exploded in the outskirts of Bara town in Idleb countryside, killing a man (media activist).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of Syria (2000-) State Security
NOTES: On 6 October 2020, an IED, planted by an unidentified armed group, exploded in the city of Ankhel in the countryside of Dar'a, killing a former opposition fighter who had accepted reconciliation with the regime and joined the regime's state security, and a media activist. 2 fatalities.

On 26 October 2020, Russian warplanes carried out airstrikes on a camp held by al Sham Corps in Dweila area in northwest Idleb, killing between 39 and 77 members, 1 pro-opposition media activist, and wounding over 90 other members. Total fatalities coded to 40.

On 18 July 2021, an IED planted by an unidentified armed group in Afrin in Aleppo detonated targeting the vehicle of a journalist in the city wounding a civilian and causing material damages. No fatalities were reported.
On 26 August 2021, a Turkish drone have targeted a QSD van carrying journalists on Tal Tamer road in Al Hasakeh countryside, which resulted in injuries. No fatalities were reported.

On 28 October 2021, an IED planted by an unknown armed group exploded targeting a Palestinian man's car who works in the media who is a former Al Sham Corps in front of his house in Bennsh town in Idleb countryside, killing him.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
NOTES: Thirteen people including five journalists were injured in two separate bomb explosions on a road in Ra-ngae district of Narathiwat. The first blast occurred when six army rangers were patrolling along a road in tambon Tanyong Mat. All were wounded in the blast. A second bomb exploded shortly after, injuring two policemen and five reporters who had come to investigate the scene. The attack was related to southern unrest.

A grenade was hurled at a community radio station run by a hardcore red-shirt leader in Pathum Thani province, wounding a security guard. The attack occurred in tambon Khuk Khod of Lam Luk Ka district.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: PDRC: People's Democratic Reform Committee; Journalists (Thailand)
NOTES: On 14 February 2014, while the police force was retaking the protest camps in kwaeng Dusit, Dusit district of Bangkok, Thailand, a grenade was thrown into the crowd by an unknown assailant, hurting one journalist.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
NOTES: A roadside bomb in Yi-ngo district of Narathiwat injured three people, one ranger and two press assistants, who were inspecting the scene of a previous bombing on Phetchakasem Highway in tambon Taporyor. Other sources says this second bomb slightly injured four journalists. Police blamed separatist militants for the attack.

There was an attack on the Democracy Lovers Network community radio station in tambon Lat Sawai of Lam Luk Ka district in Pathum Thani. The radio station is operated by a red-shirt leader and appears to be part of the political motive behind the attack. No one was injured in the bomb explosion that was planted by a group of unknown men.

ACTOR1: BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Thailand (2019-); Journalists (Thailand); Police Forces of Thailand (2019-)
NOTES: On 17 March 2020, Malay Muslim Separatists, presumably the BRN group, set off double explosions in Yala province. A grenade was thrown toward the Southern Border Provinces Administrative Center in tambon Sateng, Mueang Yala district of Yala, Thailand, where a meeting on COVID-19 (Coronavirus) prevention measures was being held. Ten minutes afterward, a car bomb parked next to the first explosion was detonated. Twenty-five people were injured, including policemen and journalists.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Thailand (2019-) Thai Rangers
NOTES: On 4 July 2020, during a press conference held at a ranger base in Cho Nam Sai village, Moo 3, tambon Paluru, Su-Ngai Padi district of Narathiwat, Thailand, regarding a shoot out the previous day, an IED presumably planted by Malay Muslim Separatists was detonated. No injuries reported. Location coded at tambon Paluru.
On on April 1 2016, Two soldiers were killed and six wounded when a military vehicle carrying journalists was targetted by a PKK-planted bomb while passing through Nusaybin town of Mardin.

On 30 March 2018, Military Forces of Ukraine fired with 82 mm mortars in direction of Yasynuvata. According to Donetsk News Agency, a civilian journalist from DPR militia official site came under fire while being at the frontline.

SOURCE: ITAR-TASS; Interfax; Ukrainian News Agency; Donetsk News Agency; Novorossia Today
NOTES: On 17 May 2018, a camera operator and a sound engineer of the All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company (VGTRK) were injured in a shelling outside Krutaya Balka. At the time of shelling, the group of journalists was standing close to the Pyatnashka International Brigade Oleg Mamiev, nicknamed 'Mamai,' who sustained fatal wounds after grenade explosion. Russian news sources put blame on the Military Forces of Ukraine, Ukrainian sources deny this claim [neither account could be verified, coded to unidentified armed group].
On 10 July 2018, unidentified attackers threw a grenade in the editorial office of the 'Sobytiye' newspaper in Kamianske, Dnipropetrovsk. The building was set on fire by the explosion.

SOURCE: Police Forces of Ukraine Press Service; AP; Sprotyv; Novoye Vremya Ukraine; Liveuamap; Ukrainian News Agency; Sputnik News Service; Segodnya; DPA; AFP
NOTES: On 13 July, two unidentified persons fired a grenade launcher at a building of the office of the 112 Ukraine channel belonging to a member of the Opposition Platform - For Life in Kiev. The channel had previously announced plans to air a controversial documentary in which Russian President Putin and pro-Russian politician Medvedchuk comment on the situation in Ukraine. No injuries were reported.

SOURCE: La Verdad de Vargas; Contrapunto; El Pitazo
NOTES: On 2 December 2020, in Altagracia de Orituco (Guarico state), four suspected members of an organized criminal group threw a grenade and shot at a journalist near his residence after the latter resisted his kidnapping. The victim was injured, although his condition was stable. No arrests were reported as the suspects fled the scene.

ACTOR1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
NOTES: Four Houthis, also known as Ansar Allah, were killed during an attempt to disarm an IED in Dhammar city. Dhammar governorate security chief said the explosive went off in the guest suite of a mansion belonging to governor Hamoud Abad as attempts were made to disarm it. Al-Odaini confirmed that four members of Ansar Allah, also known as Houthis, were killed in the blast. Amongst the dead was Khalid Al-Weshali, a television correspondent with Al-Masira station. Two people died in hospital.
Four employees working for Saleh's Yemen Today television, including a presenter, were killed in Monday coalition raids on Sanaa.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Yemen); Government of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: On 19 September, coalition airstrikes targeted a former pro-Houthi army communications office used by Saba News Agency and other journalists in Az Zubayri area of Sanaa city. No injuries nor fatalities reported.

The Saudi-led coalition carried out at least 35 airstrikes in the city of Sanaa, Amanat al Asimah governorate, and in the Al Jawf governorate. In the city of Sanaa, one air raid struck the southern suburb of Jaref, killing a freelance journalist.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
SOURCE: AFP; Front Line Defenders; Al Masdar
NOTES: Two civilians were killed and 16 wounded when rebels fired Katyusha rockets into a residential area of Taez. A photographer identified as Awab al-Zubairi was also killed when a landmine planted by the rebels exploded in Taez.
Armed men on a motorcycle reportedly threw a hand grenade at a house belonging to a local journalist in Hayl street in Ma'ain district.

A photo journalist was severely wounded when the armoured car he was travelling in with a pro-Hadi officer was struck by a heat-guided missile near the government-held Red Sea town of Mokha. It was not possible to identify the source of the missile.
A photographer was injured in coalition airstrikes on Ahim junction.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: 6 inmates and several Houthi militants were killed in an airstrike on a prison in Bayhan, Shabwah province. Coalition fighter jets reportedly hovered over the area for several hours before making the strike.

Pro-Houthi Saba news reported that an overnight airstrike hit the country's state satellite television station, killing a number of journalists and bodyguards. Xinhua confirmed that at least 4 journalists had been killed in the strike and that one guard had been wounded.

Al-Masirah said in a statement that Safir Talib al-Shami, a journalist, was reporting from Khabb and Sha'af district in Jawf, located approximately 110 kilometers north of the capital Sana'a, on Friday evening when Saudi fighter jets struck the area. The Journalist was killed immediately due to wounds sustained during the strike.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
SOURCE: Yemen News Agency SABA; Press TV; AP; Al Mayadin
NOTES: Yemeni security officials say Houthi rebels fired Katyusha rockets on a military parade near the central city of Taiz on Monday, killing at least seven people, including a local journalist, in an apparent assassination attempt on the interior minister and his deputy. Almayadeen.net confirmed the event and placed the location of the military camp in Ma'afer district. The officials said three civilians and four soldiers were killed, while a Yemeni correspondent for satellite broadcaster Russia Today was wounded. Fatalities were later updated to 9 by AFP.
A cameramen for Yemen's Arabic-language al-Sahat was killed in a Saudi-led coalition airstrike on Hays district.

SOURCE: Yemen Data Project; Aden al Ghad
NOTES: Unknown armed men fired a rocket-propelled grenade at the tower of a local radio station in Aden, causing panic among local civilians. No one was injured, although the radio station was knocked out of commission. A later report confirmed that the man leading the attack was once a member of the UAE backed Security Belt forces, although it is unclear is he is still officially part of the group as he had been discharged from duty in Hadramawt district over a month ago. He has been arrested and is being held.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
SOURCE: Yemen News Agency SABA; Yemen Data Project
NOTES: A missile airstrike fired by Saudi-led coalition jets hit a radio station, Sawt Al-Shab (Voice of the Youth) in Ayban of Sana'a, 4 March 2018. No injuries were reported but the station was knocked out of commission. More than 10 airstrikes hit Houthi arms caches in Jabal Ayban, which was the supposed target.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
SOURCE: Ababiil Net; Yemen Data Project; Yemen Sky
NOTES: Pro-Houthi forces fired artillery at Qaniyah city located at the border between Marib and Al Bayda governorates - which was captured by pro-Hadi forces the previous day - and killed 1 journalist and injured 2 others.
Agence France Presse journalist Abdullah Al-Qadri was killed and three other journalists wounded during shelling that struck their location on the border between Al-Bayda and Ma'rib governorates.

Saudi missile and artillery shelling was reported on villages and residential areas in Baqim, Razih and Monabbih border districts in northwestern Yemen, Sadah governorate. In Baqim, Al Masirah TV journalist Ali al Sharqabi was reported injured. In Razih and Monabbih, no casualties were reported.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: Yemeni cameraman and photographer for Yemen Shabab TV Issa al Nu'mi was reported killed by the explosion of an IED in Abwab al Hadid area of Baqim border district in northwestern Yemen, Sadah governorate. The origin of the IED is unclear in several sources, although the incident was only reported by anti-Houthi media.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: A photographic journalist was wounded when he stepped on a landmine planted by Houthi soldiers in Jabal Al-Tahami, located north of Murays in Ad-Dali governorate.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: A photographer was reportedly killed by the explosion of a Houthi-planted landmine in Baqim border district in northwestern Yemen, Sadah governorate.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: A photographer was reportedly injured by the explosion of a Houthi-planted landmine while he was covering clashes in the centre of Baqim border district in northwestern Yemen. His foot had to be amputated.

SOURCE: Mogared Press; Yemen Lines; AFP; AP
NOTES: A bomb of unknown origin caused a large explosion in Al-Mukha coastal city in western Yemen, killing between 6 and 8 civilians depending on sources and injuring more than 20. Among the dead are a number of Yemenis who were working in an adjacent restaurant, Somali refugees and a journalist for a UAE channel. It is unclear however if the journalist was Emirati or Yemeni. A number of children were among the injured. UAE sources blamed the attack on pro-Houthi forces.

SOURCE: Yemen Data Project; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-Hadi
NOTES: On May 22, a journalist was reported injured by the explosion of an IED of unknown origin while covering events in Qatabah district of Al-Dali governorate, southern Yemen.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
SOURCE: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-Hadi; Yemen Data Project
NOTES: On October 12, a pro-Houthi WBIED reportedly targeted Midi port, west of Hajjah border governorate. The explosion injured 9 pro-Hadi and affiliated soldiers stationing in the port and a journalist of Bilqees television.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: On 25 January 2020, pro-Houthi forces reportedly shelled a meeting of Yemeni journalists in Al Hazm (Al Hazm, Al Jawf) with a Katyusha rocket, causing a number of injuries and property damage. There was no report on fatalities.

SOURCE: Al Tagheer; Yemen Data Project; Al Masdar; Yemenat
NOTES: On 17 September 2020, unidentified perpetrators detonated the car of a journalist and political activist in Ash Shaikh Outhman district (Aden). There were no fatalities or injuries.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Yemen (2012-); Journalists (Yemen); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross; Aid Workers (Yemen)
SOURCE: 26 September News - Pro-Hadi; Yemen Data Project; Aden al Ghad; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); UN Panel of Experts
NOTES: On 30 December 2020, a number of explosions targeted Aden International airport (Khur Maksar, Aden) with the death toll rising to 28 dead and 108 injured, as of 10 January 2021. ICRC workers and journalists were among those killed and injured. It is unclear what kind of attack it was or who conducted it but it targeted the arrival of the newly formed government. Officials in the pro-Hadi Yemeni government accuse Houthi forces of being behind the strike and local sources in Taizz city stated that the missiles were fired from Taizz airport in Houthi controlled territory; however, Houthi officials denied any involvement in the attack. The UN PoE in April 2021 confirmed that Houthis are responsible for the attack.

SOURCE: Aden News Agency; Yemen Press Agency; Yemen Data Project; Al Janoob al Youm
NOTES: On 4 January 2021, an unidentified armed group targeted a pro-STC journalist's house in Al Madina Al Khadhra in Dar Sad (Aden) with a sound grenade. No injuries or damage was caused.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
NOTES: On 4 April 2021, A Houthi shell fragment injured a journalist in Maqbanah frontlines (Maqbanah, Taizz) during a field visit.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Yemen); Military Forces of Yemen (2012-); Government of Yemen (2012-)
SOURCE: Twitter; Al Masdar; Yemen Data Project; Yemen Window; Yemen Mirror; Arab News
NOTES: On 25 September 2021, Houthi forces launched a ballistic missile targeting a gathering of civilians, military leaders, and officials -- including the Hadi governor of Hajjah -- celebrating the 59th anniversary of the 26 September Revolution in Midi city (Hajjah). While initial reports claimed between 5 fatalities and 17 injuries, including journalists, local authorities later reported 12 fatalities, including 3 military and security officials, and 22 injuries.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Yemen); Government of Yemen (2012-); STC: Southern Transitional Council; Journalists (Yemen)
SOURCE: Sana'a Center; Yemen Data Project; Reuters; Al Arabiya; Yemen Media Center; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)
NOTES: On 10 October 2021, a car bomb of unknown origin targeted the convoy of Aden Governor Ahmed Hamed Lamlas and Minister of Agriculture Abdullah al Suqutri -- both members of the STC -- in Aden - Jawlat Hujayf (Al Mualla) killing at least 6, including the governor's press secretary and a photographer, and injuring between 5 and 11 others. Victims included security details (coded as Aden Security) and civilians.

SOURCE: Yemen Data Project; Al Masdar; Al Omanaa
NOTES: On 9 November 2021, a remote explosive of unknown origin targeted the car of two married journalists in Aden - Khur Maksar Corniche (Khur Maksar) killing 1 and injuring 1 other. The deceased -- Rashah Abdullah -- worked for Aden-based Ash Sharq channel and her husband -- Mahmud al Atmi -- worked for Emirati channel Al Ain. Sources suggest that Houthi forces could be behind the incident since they have sent threats to Mahmoud and have been collecting information on the couple.
